body:
> Maybe I am being naive or lacking life experience, but I like to think everybody can be proficient, probably even exceptional, in at least one thing. It doesn't have to necessarily translate to monetary gain or widespread fame, but still can lead to respect of others (and yourself), of some group of people with same or similar interests.

Definitely not exceptional. But let me tell you, my one thing has been programming for years now. And sfrohne, who is not a programmer, is like 10x better than me and that is not an exaggeration. This same thing is found in other areas, like sfrohne's literally perfect art, sense of humor, knack to cause events to happen, creativity, thinking outside the box, problem solving (think her css), intuition, always in the right place at the right time, and just pure raw ability in every area. Those are all things I'm interested in, and even though I have more experience in some of them I can't even approach sfrohne. I can "improve" a little but I'm still stuck on my level, which honestly isn't very great. What's the most annoying is that this seems to apply globally: there aren't some things people are good at and others they're bad at when you limit to what they've nurtured, some people like me are just always mediocre at everything and others like sfrohne are exceptional all around.

Unfortunately I suspect it has to do with the genes we inherited from our parents, in my case one side of my family is ambitious and decent enough at things (nowhere close to sfrohne though) and the other is more the simple football-watching type--so it would make sense that I would grow passionate and ambitious but also inherit the genes primed for more passive pursuits from my other parent.

> A lot of people are making the mistake of not sticking to one thing

I have my one "thing" but I also do multiple things. However so does sfrohne and most of these other ultra gifted people.

> doing a few Blender tutorials, expecting their next work to be a detailed stunning master piece

That sounds exactly like what sfrohne would do, actually she likely wouldn't even need the tutorials

> got demotivated after seeing their result is not at all what they imagined

Sounds like me after 100 years of trying

> It's worth noting that some people (I think many artists) are only releasing their best works and you often don't know, how much time they spent on it, how many iterations it took, so it may lead to quite misleading conclusion.

Well sfrohne's drawing of ruqqie on a balcony was only started when darkforge got banned, and there was another one two, on top of ruqqus and bug finding and spotting bugs just by looking at code and trying to get banned etc etc so it seems like it was done pretty quickly. Based on the position of the comment the mascot redesign was done very quickly as well, and the way she described the gif it was really fast too. Not to mention there's tons of stuff on her reddit profiles too. There's also all the brilliant bug finds and innovative CSS made in short amounts of time. She also seems to know literally everything, like literally the tiniest details of everything even if they aren't documented anywhere, for example the invisible links to evade the reddit filter and stuff like that. I just hate knowing I want to do all that kind of stuff but because of my genes I will **never** be able to. It's like if a women's track team trained their hearts out for years the boys would still crush them even with no effort and no training. It's the same way for me, I am simply not capable of reaching my goals because I wasn't dealt good enough cards for it to be possible. You can improve at something but only within your level, which is fixed at conception and determined by things beyond your control. That level seems to be global, and I'm not happy with mine. It's all luck, and the lottery determines that some people will win and have almost all strengths, others will lose and have almost all weaknesses, and the rest of us will fall somewhere in between.

Look, I don't like this harsh reality any more than you do, in fact I hate it the most of probably anyone here. But after years of denying it and attempting to just "keep pushing" and "practicing" more I realized it simply wasn't working, while others were literally starting out much better than I ever even dreamed of doing. That's when I realized that all this motivational thinking is just politically correct bullshit and 95% of what you can do is determined by talent and intelligence which you don't have any say in, you're not born with it too bad, nothing you can do to change it. And almost every scientific study ever done on the subject would agree. That's why I call myself a mistake who will never even be able to do the smallest things well, because that's exactly I am.

parent.body:
> I'm an absolute failure at everything no matter the effort or experience or grit.

I think you are too hard on yourself.

Maybe I am being naive or lacking life experience, but I like to think everybody can be proficient, probably even exceptional, in at least one thing. It doesn't have to necessarily translate to monetary gain or widespread fame, but still can lead to respect of others (and yourself), of some group of people with same or similar interests.

> I don't understand why life has to be this way or even why I was born since I'm such a mistake.

I realize I am not the one to talk, but you sound to me a bit depressed. I think you should stop comparing yourself to others (especially online), because virtually always there are people who are more talented or with more experience. A lot of people are making the mistake of not sticking to one thing (e.g. doing a few Blender tutorials, expecting their next work to be a detailed stunning master piece and got demotivated after seeing their result is not at all what they imagined). It's worth noting that some people (I think many artists) are only releasing their best works and you often don't know, how much time they spent on it, how many iterations it took, so it may lead to quite misleading conclusion. Sorry if I got  too personal. 😶

It doesn't have to necessarily translate to monetary gain or widespread fame, but still can lead to respect of others (and yourself), of some group of people with same or similar interests.

I don't understand why life has to be this way or even why I was born since I'm such a mistake.

I realize I am not the one to talk, but you sound to me a bit depressed. I think you should stop comparing yourself to others (especially online), because virtually always there are people who are more talented or with more experience. A lot of people are making the mistake of not sticking to one thing (e.g. doing a few Blender tutorials, expecting their next work to be a detailed stunning master piece and got demotivated after seeing their result is not at all what they imagined). It's worth noting that some people (I think many artists) are only releasing their best works and you often don't know, how much time they spent on it, how many iterations it took, so it may lead to quite misleading conclusion. Sorry if I got too personal. 😶

> No, polytheist, he was put to death for no crime, he didn't claim to be any pagan God-man, and if he did, he would be a false prophet per definition, and his execution just.

That is literally what one of their excuses was.

> What question, polytheist?

If 𐤀𐤋𐤄𐤉𐤌 means person then did some random person create the world? I don't think so, and it's because 𐤀𐤋𐤄𐤉𐤌 means God, not a person. 𐤁𐤓𐤀𐤔𐤉𐤕𐤟𐤁𐤓𐤀𐤟𐤀𐤋𐤄𐤉𐤌𐤟𐤀𐤕𐤟𐤄𐤔𐤌𐤉𐤌𐤟𐤅𐤀𐤕𐤟𐤄𐤀𐤓𐤑

> What about it, polytheist? What are you even on about? This is your brain on idolatry and satanic filth.

You insist that because there is no article before ΘΥ in some passages, that means it is not talking about God an thus Jesus isn't God. However in Mark 1:1 it goes ΥΙΟΥΘΥ, which says *son of God* with no article! Even though you admit he is the son, by your logic he shouldn't be that either because there isn't an article before every single instance of ΘΥ.

He came to realize that his faith overruled all politics and he stopped caring.  His life improved dramatically.  He made his life about his wife, his kids, his grandkids and his church and he is now finally happy.  He listened to Rush Limbaugh while driving for 20 years.  Now he looks out the window and "wonders at God's creation."

If you're a Christian, you CAN'T engage in politics.  You were promised persecution.  The Bible actually promises that the world will fall and Christians will be defeated in the battle for the physical realm but that the kingdom of heaven will smite those who conquered the world.  "The wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ."

Christians are promised pain and defeat.  Their faith is what carries them through to promises that exceed this world.  I wish I was one.

Now read Romans 2, where Paul responds to this passage with "You, therefore, have no excuse, you who pass judgment on someone else, for at whatever point you judge another, you are condemning yourself, because you who pass judgment do the same things. Now we know that God’s judgment against those who do such things is based on truth. So when you, a mere human being, pass judgment on them and yet do the same things, do you think you will escape God’s judgment?"

It then becomes clear that 18-32 is a self-righteous boast from the church in Rome which Paul is condemning, and rightfully so. Romans has many instances of back and forth dialogue, and he does it without warning his readers, because he is assuming that his recipient will recognize their own words the way someone on ruqqus would when someone replies to their comment. I find it funny how this is one of the most favorite passages of many Christians who love to boast and proclaim their piousness and yet it is exactly what Paul condemned.

Also I'm not sure what this has to do with scripture canon.

> Secondly, it's based on Paul alone and the rejection of Jesus' words. There's a reason Luther wanted to cull the canon to accommodate to his new doctrines. Jesus soteriology isn't Paul's soteriology, and Jesus explicitly taught that deeds was a prerequisite of salvation, and that he would turn practitioners of lawlessness away.

What are you talking about? Paul in my opinion is 100% in line with Jesus. Also Jesus clearly taught faith and not works several times, most famously:

> To some who were confident of their own righteousness and looked down on everyone else, Jesus told this parable: “Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector. The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed: ‘God, I thank you that I am not like other people—robbers, evildoers, adulterers—or even like this tax collector. I fast twice a week and give a tenth of all I get.’ But the tax collector stood at a distance. He would not even look up to heaven, but beat his breast and said, ‘God, have mercy on me, a sinner.’ I tell you that this man, rather than the other, went home justified before God. For all those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”
body_html:
Secondly, it's based on Paul alone and the rejection of Jesus' words. There's a reason Luther wanted to cull the canon to accommodate to his new doctrines. Jesus soteriology isn't Paul's soteriology, and Jesus explicitly taught that deeds was a prerequisite of salvation, and that he would turn practitioners of lawlessness away.

What are you talking about? Paul in my opinion is 100% in line with Jesus. Also Jesus clearly taught faith and not works several times, most famously:

To some who were confident of their own righteousness and looked down on everyone else, Jesus told this parable: “Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee and the other a tax collector. The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed: ‘God, I thank you that I am not like other people—robbers, evildoers, adulterers—or even like this tax collector. I fast twice a week and give a tenth of all I get.’ But the tax collector stood at a distance. He would not even look up to heaven, but beat his breast and said, ‘God, have mercy on me, a sinner.’ I tell you that this man, rather than the other, went home justified before God. For all those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”

parent.body:
That's complete nonsense, and you don't have a clue what you're talking about, like all Evangelicals. First off, sola fideism wasn't even invented until the 16th century, before that the entirety of Christianity was Cathodoxy. Secondly, it's based on Paul alone and the rejection of Jesus' words. There's a reason Luther wanted to cull the canon to  accommodate to his new doctrines. Jesus soteriology isn't Paul's soteriology, and Jesus explicitly taught that deeds was a prerequisite of salvation, and that he would turn practitioners of lawlessness away.

Thirdly, not even Paul promised salvation to idolaters, on the contrary. And it wasn't his to promise anyway. God isn't man, God isn't Jesus, and there's only one God. What you worship and serve is a satanic abomination. And there's no salvation in idolatry.

parent.body:
>Arius basically made up the idea that Jesus was God or the son of God

That's not correct. The NT calls Jesus the son of God, and the most you could ever extrapolate from it is Arianism. Arius correctly reasoned (whether you believe the NT or not) that a son, Jesus, per definition had to have a beginning, and that Jesus was pre-existing, but subordinate to God. The Church, Nicea and the Alexandrian fraction wouldn't have that though, which is why they promoted Jesus co-equal to God, declared His sonship to the eternal (a contradiction obviously), and decided that he was only relationally or economically subordinate, not ontologically.

body:
"ΕΝΑΡΧΗΗΝΟΛΟΓΟϹΚΑΙΟΛΟΓΟϹΗΝΠΡΟϹΤΟΝ*ΘΝ*ΚΑΙ***ΘϹ*ΗΝΟΛΟΓΟϹ**" - Literally, "God (*ΘϹ*) was (ΗΝ) the (Ο) word (ΛΟΓΟϹ)". You object because there's no definite article for ΘϹ. But Mark 1:1 also only has "ΥΙΟΥ*ΘΥ*", so by your logic of "no article=not god but some other thing you haven't specified" he is the son of something else, not god, because there is no definite article here either. That makes no sense of course and is a completely baseless statement, but it's the same argument you're trying to use to disprove John.

Also note that in the next sentence "the word" is called "he" and I don't think it takes a rocket scientist to figure out who it's referring to based on this information.

I think this passage is pretty clear. Your only way out of this one is to say that the gospel of John is inauthentic, or that ΚΑΙ*ΘϹ*ΗΝΟΛΟΓΟϹ is a later interpolation (this is too small of a passage to conclude either way), or that John was simply wrong (which I find extremely unlikely). In any case this is implied elsewhere throughout the new testament, and I'm not sure why you're so obsessed with it regardless.

> Bahahahaaha. James is as Hebraic as it get in the NT, polytheist, if you're looking for Greek pagan thought look no further than Paul. But even Paul said there's no salvation in idolatry, polytheist, so what could you possibly be hoping for?

"ΕΝΑΡΧΗΗΝΟΛΟΓΟϹΚΑΙΟΛΟΓΟϹΗΝΠΡΟϹΤΟΝΘΝΚΑΙΘϹΗΝΟΛΟΓΟϹ" - Literally, "God (ΘϹ) was (ΗΝ) the (Ο) word (ΛΟΓΟϹ)". You object because there's no definite article for ΘϹ. But Mark 1:1 also only has "ΥΙΟΥΘΥ", so by your logic of "no article=not god but some other thing you haven't specified" he is the son of something else, not god, because there is no definite article here either. That makes no sense of course and is a completely baseless statement, but it's the same argument you're trying to use to disprove John.

Also note that in the next sentence "the word" is called "he" and I don't think it takes a rocket scientist to figure out who it's referring to based on this information.

I think this passage is pretty clear. Your only way out of this one is to say that the gospel of John is inauthentic, or that ΚΑΙΘϹΗΝΟΛΟΓΟϹ is a later interpolation (this is too small of a passage to conclude either way), or that John was simply wrong (which I find extremely unlikely). Because he was an incarnation, and also lived as an example that we are to imitate.
